item.title: Quick Data Plotting in R - II
item.description: In the first part of the posts on R, I outlined a couple of useful strategies for quick exploratory data analysis and visualization using R programming language. In this post, I will share a few more examples (in a case-study like manner) along with relevant plots for better demonstration.

item.title: Diving Deeper into BLAST - III
item.description: BLAST+ is an incredible tool and does it job in a pretty decent way. However, anyone who has worked with it for some time with some non trivial details has their own horror stories to tell.

item.title: Diving Deeper into BLAST - II
item.description: This is a follow up of the previous post where I was trying to parse the BLAST+ XML output to create an efficient data layer in SequenceServer. A critical and often demanded feature for the application was the ability to have a graphical overview of all the obtained hits.

item.title: Diving Deeper into BLAST - I
item.description: In my previous post, I mentioned about a project I was trying to work on: SequenceServer. Also, in the end I said that I would be writing about the BLAST algorithm (which is the backbone of this project) and how does it works so efficiently in producing alignments even with very long sequences.

item.title: Introduction to Sequenceserver
item.description: Contributing to open source is quite an exciting journey. I embarked upon this path recently with few contributions to SequenceServer - A BLAST tool, a bioinformatics software built around BLAST+ that lets you setup a custom BLAST+ server to perform BLAST queries with your own database locally through a web interface.
